item.title: England's lockdown to ease as planned on 12 April
item.description: Outdoor hospitality, all shops, gyms and hairdressers can reopen but the PM warns against complacency.

item.title: Richard Okorogheye: Police find body in search for missing student
item.description: Richard Okorogheye was last seen by his family on 22 March, when he left their home in west London.

item.title: Harvey Weinstein appeals against conviction for sex crimes
item.description: The former film producer was found guilty of two sex crimes in February 2020 and jailed for 23 years.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Hairdressers and homeware shops reopen
item.description: Non-essential click and collect services are also able to resume business as Covid restrictions ease.

item.title: Tory MP Dame Cheryl Gillan dies after long illness
item.description: PM Boris Johnson pays tribute to the former Welsh secretary, saying she will be "sorely missed".

item.title: Covid: 'All over-50s in Wales offered vaccine by target date'
item.description: All over-50s and at-risk adults have been offered a vaccine, the Welsh government says.

item.title: Thandie Newton reverts to original spelling of first name, Thandiwe
item.description: The actress has previously been known as Thandie, an anglicised version of her name.

item.title: Netanyahu trial: Editor 'told to drop negative stories about Israel PM'
item.description: The Israeli PM's corruption trial is told he sought improper benefits from media bosses.

item.title: Mozambique town Palma 'retaken' from militant Islamists
item.description: The military says it is now fully in control of Palma, which was invaded by militants on 24 March.

item.title: Car crash baby death: Parents pay tribute to two-week-old hit by car
item.description: The parents of a two-week-old boy whose pram was crushed say their "hearts will always ache".

item.title: Taiwan train crash: 'Can you let me hug her again?'
item.description: Survivors of Taiwan's worst rail accident in decades share their heartbreaking stories of loss.

item.title: Jordan's Prince Hamzah vows to defy 'house arrest' orders
item.description: Prince Hamzah says he will not stay quiet after he was accused of plotting to destabilise the state.

item.title: Dubai police arrest group over nude balcony shoot
item.description: Eleven Ukrainian women were among those detained, the Ukrainian consulate told the BBC.

item.title: SAG Awards: Screen Actors Guild honour The Trial of the Chicago 7
item.description: People from ethnic minorities win in all four individual film categories for the first time.

item.title: Madden NFL: The England cricketer who is starring in the gaming world
item.description: How England physical disability cricketer Liam O'Brien has become one of the best in the world at the Madden NFL computer game.

item.title: Fun but doomed: LG's most memorable smartphones
item.description: The South Korean firm is giving up on mobiles after repeatedly trying to out-innovate the market.

item.title: Sudden death: Partner's heartache after her fiancé died aged 31
item.description: Danielle Riley shares her grief after losing her partner Andy to Sudden Adult Death Syndrome.

item.title: Tigray crisis: The Weeknd donates $1m to Ethiopians in conflict
item.description: The Canadian popstar says his "heart breaks for innocent civilians being senselessly murdered".

item.title: Boohoo: Karen Millen skirt had Oasis label covered in pen
item.description: Joanna Sikora said a skirt she bought from Karen Millen had an Oasis label covered in marker pen.

item.title: Patria y Vida: Cuba's rap battle with dissidents
item.description: A viral YouTube rap and reggaeton hit called 'Patria y Vida' - 'Fatherland and Life' - has angered Cuba's communist-run government.

item.title: Adopting a child with an opioid addiction
item.description: Carrie Brady didn’t realise how the decision to adopt would reshape her family’s life forever.

item.title: Covid: Croquet clubs 'inundated' during lockdown
item.description: The UK croquet season begins as clubs see a spike in membership enquiries.

item.title: A55 Easter traffic brought to standstill as horse 'breaks down'
item.description: The equine brought the A55 in Gwynedd to a standstill when its vehicle broke down.

item.title: Can celebrities control their image online?
item.description: Meet the stars who have attempted to police their online presence - from Rami Malek to Beyonce.

item.title: Gundecha Brothers: Famous Indian music gurus accused of sexual assault
item.description: The BBC spoke to several women who have accused three famous classical musicians of sexual abuse.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: How the virus has changed our sleep patterns
item.description: Coronavirus is clearly a virus that affects our nervous system - and it appears to have an impact on the brain's sleep patterns.

item.title: Covid Greece: Waiting for the tourists to come back
item.description: As Europeans wait to see if foreign holidays are possible this summer, Greece hopes to open up soon.

item.title: Vitamin D: The truth about an alleged Covid ‘cover-up’
item.description: The vitamin is being studied - but why do some claim evidence is being ignored?

item.title: The Myanmar beauty queen standing up to the military
item.description: A month ago Han Lay was protesting. Last week she used her pageant speech to criticise the military.

item.title: Extreme E: How did women and men's performances compare in Desert X-Prix?
item.description: In a brand new motorsport promoting equality between women and men, how did their performances compare in the first of five X-Prixs?

item.title: Everton 1-1 Crystal Palace: Late Michy Batshuayi leveller dents Toffees' Champions League hopes
item.description: Crystal Palace's Michy Batshuayi scores a late equaliser to dent Everton's Champions League qualification hopes.

item.title: Struggling Sheffield Wednesday hit Cardiff for five
item.description: Sheffield Wednesday move to within six points of Championship safety as they hammer Cardiff City 5-0.

item.title: England and West Ham midfielder Rice out for a month
item.description: West Ham midfielder Declan Rice is expected to be out for four weeks after injuring his knee on international duty with England.

item.title: Watch: Middlesbrough's Millie Bell scores 35-yard screamer in Women's FA Cup
item.description: Watch as Middlesbrough's Mille Bell scores a 35-yard free-kick in her side's 3-1 Women's FA Cup win against Hull.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: What are the UK plans for Covid passports?
item.description: A government review is considering whether people will need to prove they have been vaccinated.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The rules on how many people can meet outdoors are changing, as lockdown is eased.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pools, gyms, pubs and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pubs and gyms?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 31 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: When can pubs and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Hospitality venues are set to gradually open up in the spring as lockdown eases across the UK.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for places of worship?
item.description: Places of worship are open across much of the UK, despite lockdown.

item.title: How many cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Why is the EU unhappy with AstraZeneca?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but the rules are easing.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Covid: What's happened to crime during the pandemic?
item.description: From dog theft to drug crime, lockdown has led to some big changes in policing.

item.title: What are the rules on dating now? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: The cost of speaking up against China
item.description: Uyghurs abroad describe a pattern of harassment and intimidation they say is designed to silence them.

item.title: Letterbox contact: ‘Don’t my birth children have a right to know I’m dying?'
item.description: Diagnosed with a terminal illness, Hanna wanted to tell the twins taken from her at 16 - but had no way of reaching them.

item.title: 'We found a baby on the subway - now he's our son'
item.description: Danny Stewart saw something on the floor of an NY subway station - soon he would treasure it more than anything.

item.title: Naga Munchetty: It’s time to talk about race
item.description: Naga Munchetty travelled across the UK to understand what race and racism means today.
